awd_titl_txt: Low-cost Manufacturing of Carbon Fibers Using Laser Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon fibers are important engineering materials for lightweight structures due to their high specific stiffness and strength. It has been demonstrated that carbon fibers play an important role in civil engineering construction, aerospace field, automotive systems, athletic equipment, etc. Using carbon fiber composites to replace metals used in core structures of body shells in passenger automobiles can reduce vehicle weight by as much as 60%. This can result in fuel savings and less carbon dioxide emissions, having positive impacts on energy consumption and the environment. However, carbon fibers have not been widely used in various systems, especially automotive systems. The largest obstacle is the high cost of carbon fiber manufacturing. This award supports fundamental research on a new manufacturing process for fabricating carbon fibers with low cost. Compared with the current carbon fiber manufacturing process, the new process can potentially dramatically shorten the process time, achieve high-energy efficiency, lower manufacturing cost, and improve properties of carbon fibers. Results from this research will enable the wider use of carbon fibers as lightweight and strong engineering materials in broad applications.

The new manufacturing process for fabricating carbon fibers uses laser processing to convert stabilized polyacrylonitrile precursor fibers to carbon fibers (carbonization) and carbon fibers to graphite fibers (graphitization). The research objective is to understand the effects of laser processing parameters (laser wavelength, power, mode, scan speed, and beam profile) on fiber microstructure and mechanical properties. To achieve this objective, experiments will be conducted using a CO2 laser with wavelength of 10.6 micrometer and a solid-state laser with wavelength of 532 nm. Laser power (less than 5 W), laser mode (continuous or pulsed), and scan speed (up to 25 cm/s) will be varied. Laser beam profile will be adjusted to introduce preheating and control temperature distribution in the fiber. The typical length of the fibers will be within 30 cm, and typical diameter around 7 micrometer. Fiber microstructure will be observed by using electron microscopy and evaluated in terms of bonding status (measured by FTIR and Raman microscopy) and crystallinity (by X-ray diffraction). Mechanical properties (tensile strength, modulus, and failure strain) of fibers will be measured by dynamic mechanical analyzer.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Carbon fibers (CFs) are an important engineering material that can be used for producing lightweight structures due to their high specific tensile modulus and strength. CFs can play a vital role in such areas as civil engineering construction, aerospace and automotive industries, and athletic equipment. Using CF composites to replace metals used in the core structure of automobiles could reduce a vehicle’s weight by as much as 60%, resulting infuel savings and less carbon dioxide emissions. The impact on reducing energy consumption and protecting the environment would be significant. However, CF acceptance by various industries, especially the automotive industry, is still lacking, with the largest obstacle being the cost of CF manufacturing. This project, titled “Low-cost Manufacturing of Carbon Fibers Using Laser Processing”, explored laser processing technology for carbon fiber and graphite fiber (GF) manufacturing. During the project period, we investigated the effects of laser processing parameters on fabrication of CFs and GFs through the carbonization and graphitization of the precursor fibers, characterized the morphology and the chemical, mechanical, and electrical properties of the resultant fibers at each process stage in order to better understand the process-structure-property relationships and developed the irradiation processes to control the outcomes of the laser irradiation.

Experiments were conducted using a CO2 laser at a wavelength of 10.6 micrometers. The laser power (less than 5 W), laser mode (continuous-pulse), and scan speed (up to 25 cm/s) were varied. Laser beam profiles were adjusted to preheat and to control temperature distribution and heating times of the fibers. The possible temperature profile of a fiber under different laser scan conditions were modeled. In this project, the stabilized polyacrylonitrile (PAN) fiber was chosen as the starting material for the carbonization process investigation and T300 carbon fiber (Toray Carbon Fibers America) for the graphitization study. Laser irradiation was performed by scanning along the fiber axis in a nitrogen environment. Fiber microstructures were observed using electron microscopy (SEM) and evaluated in terms of bonding status, which were examined by FTIR and Raman microscopy. A 2-probe method measured the electrical properties, and a dynamic mechanical analyzer examined the mechanical properties of tensile strength, modulus, and failure strain.

During the laser scans, strong light luminescence emitted from the fiber was observed as an illuminated spot that followed the scan of the laser beam. Luminescence intensity increases with laser power and decreases with increasing scan speed. The strong luminescence from the fiber indicates that the fiber temperature at the area was higher than 1000 °C. The Raman spectra showed structural changes in the fiber were uniform, and the structure changes depended on the laser power density. The IR and Raman spectra indicated that the carbonization of the stabilized PAN fiber was accomplished after the proper laser scan. After the laser scan, the resistance of the fiber changed from mega ohm per centimeter level to less than kilo ohm level, and the mechanical properties were similar to commercial T300 carbon fiber. The SEM observation confirmed that the diameter of fiber decreased from 10 micrometers (stabilized PAN fiber’s diameter) to ~7 micrometers (typical CF’s diameter) after laser irradiation, and no pores were observed in the fiber. The results indicate that laser processing technology may be applied for CF manufacturing. When T300 fibers were scanned by laser at a relatively higher power, Raman spectra showed that the D band and G band were sharper and the 2D band appeared. As the intensity of G band increased, the ratio of G band to D band also increased, which indicates that the graphitization was introduced by using laser processing technology.

Controlling the temperature and temperature profile in the fiber under laser irradiation is important. Fast laser scans and high laser power leads to high temperature levels and faster heating and cooling of the fiber, which generate pores within the fiber during the carbonization process. Although the fiber is a porous structure, the solid part is well carbonized. The pores size and distribution were discovered to be controllable. Laser processing technology was found to also be capable of producing porous carbon fibers, which was an unexpected outcome of this project.

Compared to current CF manufacturing processes, laser-processing technology can dramatically shorten processing time, resulting in greater energy efficiency. It is expected that the laser processing would provide the capability to tailor the microstructure of the fibers for affordable high-performance CF and GF manufacturing, which would be demonstrated in our future research. 


Last Modified: 04/01/2019
Modified by: Mei Zhang
